data.title: The new Brazilian president’s first pick for science minister was a creationist. He chose a soybean tycoon who has deforested large tracts of the Amazon rain forest to be his agriculture minister. And he is the first leader in decades to have no women in his Cabinet.
Pakistan’s ‘Billion Tree Tsunami’ gains momentum, hopes to achieve target of One Billion new saplings plantation by end of next year.
Syria Army killed over 200 ISIS militants in 3-day long offensive in Deir Ezzor
Muslim states block 11 LGBT groups from attending UN Aids meeting
Israel Antiquities Authority announces the biggest archaeological find in 30 years -- A 1600-year-old Roman shipwreck filled with bronze statues and coins bearing the face of Constantine the Great.
Caribbean islands warned as Venezuela collapses

Barcelona’s plan to give streets back to residents. The Catalan capital’s radical new strategy will restrict traffic to a number of big roads, drastically reducing pollution and turning secondary streets into ‘citizen spaces’ for culture, leisure and the community.
Face recognition app taking Russia by storm may bring end to public anonymity

Australian Energy Boss Emails Climate-Change Skeptic Handbook.Prominent businessman and donor to the Australian Liberal Party, accidentally emailed hundreds of politicians and elites a 16-page handbook.The handbook explains how to argue that climate-change is not human-made.
Mexican President Proposes Legalizing Gay Marriage
Prominent Oceans Scientist Fails to Disclose Funding From Fishing Industry
Revealed: Saudi Arabia owns $117 billion of U.S. debt
North Korea is last place Americans should travel to warns US State Department
Pirate Party set to be kingmaker in next Icelandic parliament—polls
Russia to revive missile trains as U.S. launches European missile defense system
